body.head.byline: Special to The New York Times

block.p: Pete Weber's fate was in his hands today at the $150,000 Johnny Petraglia Open, and after throwing a strike and a nine on his first two balls in the 10th frame, those hands were raised in triumph.

Last week, Weber and a national television audience, watched in disbelief as Del Ballard Jr., who needed seven pins to win the Fair Lanes Open in Baltimore, rolled a gutter ball in the 10th frame to give Weber a gift victory. "I love it," said Weber,of Florissant, Mo., holding up a crystal trophy with a check for $27,000 folded inside. "I wasn't sitting on the bench this time. I won it outright."
Pete Weber's fate was in his hands today at the $150,000 Johnny Petraglia Open, and after throwing a strike and a nine on his first two balls in the 10th frame, those hands were raised in triumph.

Last week, Weber and a national television audience, watched in disbelief as Del Ballard Jr., who needed seven pins to win the Fair Lanes Open in Baltimore, rolled a gutter ball in the 10th frame to give Weber a gift victory. "I love it," said Weber,of Florissant, Mo., holding up a crystal trophy with a check for $27,000 folded inside. "I wasn't sitting on the bench this time. I won it outright."

Weber, whose open fourth frame put him 15 pins behind Bob Benoit of Topeka, Kan., in the championship match, rallied with six consecutive strikes and pulled away for a 244-234 victory. Needing five pins to clinch the match on his second ball in the 10th frame, Weber eschewed his usual sweeping hook shot and threw a straight ball, knocking down nine pins.
In a similar situation last week, Ballard went for a strike, and came up empty.
